awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EHR Core: Exploring the Emotional and Motivational Lives of Undergraduate Engineering Students
awd_abstract_narration:
A strong engineering workforce is critical to maintaining a dynamic and innovative United States economy. Engineering programs present considerable challenges, including the need to motivate students and the need for students to have positive attitudes toward learning. Prior research demonstrates that high motivation and positive attitudes towards learning occur when students feel in control of their own learning, place a high value on what they are studying, can regulate their anxiety, and recover from setbacks.  While asking students questions about these issues is useful, there is a more direct way to study them - by measuring students' physical responses in real time. A unique element of this study is that in addition to surveys, the investigators will monitor students' body stress responses through sweat and saliva to capture students' anxiety during an exam. The intellectual merit of this ECR project is to broaden understanding of factors related to success using physical signs that a student cannot consciously control and of which they may not even be aware. The broader impacts of this research will come from integrating students' reported perceptions with their unconscious responses to better understand students' emotional and motivational responses to learning, especially those of underrepresented students, who face even greater challenges.  This ECR project will support innovative learning environments that promote student success and entrance into the workforce.

More specifically, the intellectual merit of this project is to extend theories of motivation and emotion by integrating physiological responses of students with more traditional measures to better predict student beliefs and behaviors, as well as performance on accepted metrics of success in engineering programs. In addition to surveys, we will use physiological markers based on sweat on the skin (electrodermal activity) and saliva (particularly hormonal markers) to capture students' emotion and anxiety during an authentic exam setting associated with a foundational engineering course. The project will also be integrative in drawing upon theoretical and practical knowledge from engineering education, psychology, physiology, and the learning sciences. It will also broaden understanding of factors related to student emotion, motivation and self-regulation using physical signals that a student cannot self-report as they cannot consciously control and may not even be aware of. The broader impact will come from applying these findings to improving student outcomes, especially those of underrepresented students, who are trying to succeed in an especially challenging environment.

por.por_cntn:
Our project advanced our understanding of the relation between testing conditions, self-beliefs, emotions, and performance.  Additionally, our research advanced our understanding of the potential for biological and physiological markers of arousal to study emotions and performance.

Students' emotional lives infuse every aspect of learning, including how they perform and are affected by testing. Our goal is to enrich our understanding of performance by supplementing existing cognitively-based studies of learning and performance by exploring their emotional responses in testing situations.

If researchers want to know how students are feeling, they simply ask them what they are feeling. There are several drawbacks to this approach, however. Students may not even know how they feel exactly, caught up in the moment and focused on performing well than on self-reflection. Advances in technology and understanding the relationship between thought and physical responses allow us to stop relying on self-report.

In a series of studies, we collected saliva and measured changes in sweat before, during, and after a test that measured what students learned in an actual class, creating as authentic a situation as possible. By examining how cortisol and levels of sweat rise and fall, we could create a picture of the emotional ups and downs, they experience during the test. We measure sweat using a device much like a wristwatch; to collect saliva, we ask them to hold a cotton ball against the inside of their cheek. Students tolerate both without complaint and are easy to use in a variety of situations. One of the broader impacts of our study is the demonstration of the viability of these methods for examining test-taking emotions.

We all know the feeling of our palms growing damp when we feel stressed and when we feel excited. Using electrodermal activity (a measure of the amount of micro-sweat) methods, we can tell when a person's emotions are rising. Our research has shown that this technology can determine if changes in sweat are due to mental effort or fear. This advance will allow future researchers to understand better the impact of the environment or testing conditions on students' emotions.  We can use this simple, unobtrusive measure to examine tests, testing environments, and prepare students to have the best experience possible.

One of the benefits of our work has been to provide instructors with a better understanding of the emotional impact of test-taking.  Our results will focus faculty on the emotional and human dimensions of their students.  Additionally, due to our ability to tell "working hard" from fear, we can provide a window into students' exam-taking experience and help teachers better serve their students through better test construction. Faculty may want to construct a "hard test." Understanding that teacher-made tests are imperfect is not new. However, we can now investigate the emotional impact of the mismatch between facultys' and students' exam experience. We found that faculty's expectation for the difficulty of a test problem did not match either students' experience of the item as difficulty or the effort they put forward (as measured by the "working hard" changes is sweat). These findings can help us produce more reliable, valid, and informative tests. We also found that spending more time on a single question did not affect the outcome; this finding can help students strategize how to approach a test.

In addition to measuring changes in students' micro-sweat using electrodermal activity monitors, we collected students' saliva. Saliva contains the chemical cortisol, the concentration of which rises as we become more stressed.

We learned from measuring cortisol through students' saliva that most students feel the most stress before and near the end of the exam; during the exam, cortisol drops, presumably as students begin to focus more on the test and less about worrying about how they will do. But this is not always the case. For example, some students may arrive with high hopes, only finding the test more challenging than expected. These students do not have a drop in cortisol. Their levels remain high throughout the exam.  Although this hormone is an essential part of our ability to ready ourselves for a challenging task, it can interfere with our ability to perform in exam settings.  Students who doubt their ability to perform face both a difficult test and a brain that works less effectively because of the arousal caused by their lack of confidence.  These findings demonstrate a need to support students both in their self-beliefs and in stress reduction strategies.

In summary, our work provides evidence for the importance of understanding the shifting emotional experiences of students as they try to perform demanding tasks.
